G8514	ὀμφαλός	omphalos	anavel		1. the navel, Lat. umbilicus, (Iliad by Homer), etc. 2. anything central (like a navel): 3. the knob or boss in the middle of the shield, Lat. umbo, (Iliad by Homer) 4. a button or knob on the horse's yoke to fasten the reins to, (Iliad by Homer) 5. in plural the knobs at each end of the stick round which books were rolled, Lat. umbilici, (Lucian) 6. the centre or middle point, as the island of Calypso is the ὀμφαλός of the sea, (Odyssey by Homer); and Delphi (or rather a round stone in the Delphic temple) was called ὀμφαλός as marking the middle point of Earth, (Pindar), etc. (ML)

G8862	πονέω	poneō	to suffer pain		1. in early Greek only as Dep. 2. absolute to work hard, do work, suffer toil; περὶ δόρπα πονέοντο were busied about their supper; so, πεπόνητο καθ᾽ ἵππους was busy with the horses, of a charioteer, 3. metaphorically to be in distress, to distress oneself; to suffer, be sick, 4. with accusative to work hard at, to make or do with pains or care, 5. after, the active form prevails 6. intransitive to toil, labour, attic; μάτην π. to labour in vain; with accusative, τὰ μηδὲν ὠφελοῦντα μὴ πόνει do not labour at things that profit not, 7. with accusative cognate, π. πόνον, μόχθους to go through, suffer them, [variant dates Tragica Adespota; also with accusative partis, πονεῖν τὰ σκέλη 8. absolute to labour, be hard-pressed, suffer: to be worn out, spoilt, 9. Pass, impersonal, οὐκ ἄλλως αὐτοῖς πεπόνηται = πεπονήκασι, 10. transitive, 11. with accusative pers. to afflict, distress;Pass. to be worn out, to suffer greatly, 12. Pass, also, to be trained or educated, 13. with accusative rei, like ἐκπονεῖν, to gain by toil or labour, χρήματα: Pass. to be won or achieved by toil, (ML)

G8881	πρέσβυς	presbus	an ambassador		1. an old man, Lat. senex, (the prose form is πρεσβύτης); ὁ πρέσβυς is used much like ὁ πρεσβύτερος, the elder; plural πρέσβεις, elders, always implying dignity, chiefs, princes; epic πρέσβηες 2. uses only the comparative and Sup, comparative πρεσβύτερος, α, ον, elder, older, attic; ἐνιαυτῷ by a year; βουλαὶ πρεσβύτεραι the wise councils of age;Sup. πρεσβύτατος, η, ον, eldest, etc;the comparative and Sup. were used of things, πρεσβύτερόν τι (or οὐδὲν); ἔχειν = Lat. aliquid (or nihil) antiquius habere, to deem higher, more important, τὰ τοῦ θεοῦ πρεσβύτερα ποιεῖσθαι ἢ τὰ τῶν ἀνδρῶν; πρεσβύτατον κρίνειν τι; πρεσβυτέρως γυμναστικὴν μουσικῆς τετιμηκέναι more highly than;hence, merely of magnitude, πρεσβύτερον κακὸν κακοῦ one evil greater than another, 3. like πρεσβευτής, an ambassador; plural πρέσβεις is more used than πρεσβευταί, etc. 4. a chief, president: comparative πρεσβύτερος, an elder of the Jewish Council, etc: an elder of the Church, presbyter, (ML)

G8896	προΐημι	proiēmi	to let go		1. to send before, send on or forward: also, to send something to another, ἀγγελίας, φήμην often with an infinitive added; αἰετὼ προέηκα πέτεσθαι, οὖρον προέηκεν ἀῆναι 2. to send away, dismiss, let go; τήνδε θεῷ πρόες let her go to the god, i. e. in reverence to him, 3. to let loose, let fall, especially thoughtlessly, ἔπος προέηκε let drop a word; πηδάλιον ἐκ χειρῶν προέηκε he let the helm slip from his hands; δάκρυα προῆκεν 4. of missiles, to send forth, shoot or dart forth, 5. of a river, ὕδωρ προί̈ει ἐς Πηνειόν it pours its water into the Peneius, 6. πρ. τινί ποιεῖν τι to allow one to do, 7. to give up, deliver over, betray one to his enemy;Pass. to be given or thrown away, εἰ προεῖτο ταῦτα 8. ἐπὶ τὸ αὐτίκα ἡδὺ πρ. αὑτόν to give up or devote oneself to present delights, 9. G8975	πτερόν	pteron	a feather		1. mostly in plural feathers, etc; in singular a feather, 2. = πτέρυξ, a bird's wing, in plural wings; Παλλάδος ὑπὸ πτεροῖς ὄντας, metaphorically from chickens under the hen's wings; τῷ πτερὰ γίγνετο he got as it were wings, i. e. spirit, courage, 3. the wings of a bat (see. πτίλον II), 4. any winged creature, as the Sphinx; a beetle, 5. like οἰωνός, Lat. avis, an augury, omen, 6. anything like wings: as 7. a ship's wings, i. e. oars (compare πτερόω); ἐρετμά, τά τε πτερὰ νηυσὶ πέλονται; νηὸς πτερά; hence birds are said πτεροῖς ἐρέσσειν, 8. ἀέθλων πτερά, i. e. the wings of victory, which lift the Poet to heaven, 9. a feathered arrow, 10. τοῦ πώγωνος τὰ πτερά the points of the beard, 11. in Architecture, of the rows of columns along the sides of Greek temples, see. ἄπτερος. G9122	σκυτάλη	skutalē	a stave		1. a staff, cudgel, club, [variant dates Anthology Palantina 2. at Sparta, a staff or baton, used as a cypher for writing dispatches;a strip of leather was rolled slantwise round it, on which the dispatches were written lengthwise, so that when unrolled they were unintelligible: commanders abroad had a staff of like thickness, round which they rolled these papers, and so were able to read the dispatches;hence σκυτάλη came to mean a Spartan dispatch; and generally a message, derivation uncertain (ML)

G9130	σοφιστής	sophistēs	a wise man		1. a master of one's craft or art, an adept, of a diviner; of poets; of the Creator; metaphorically, ς. πημάτων an adept in misery, 2. like φρόνιμος, one who is clever in matters of life, a wise man, in which sense the seven Sages are called σοφισταί; of Prometheus, 3. at Athens, a Sophist, i. e. a professor of grammar, rhetoric, politics, mathematics, such as Prodicus, Gorgias, Protagoras, etc. At first the Sophists were held in honour; but from their loose principles they fell into ill repute, and the word came to mean, 4. a sophist (in bad sense), a quibbler, cheat, etc. (ML)

G9259	σύμβολον	sumbolon	a symbol		1. a sign or token by which one infers a thing, [variant dates Tragica Adespota; λαμπάδος τὸ σύμβολον the token of the beacon-fire;often in plural, of marks on the body; of omens, 2. a pledge or pawn, on which money was advanced, 3. in plural tallies, Lat. tesserae hospitales, i.e. the halves of a bone or coin, which two persons broke between them, each keeping one piece, etc. 4. at Athens, a ticket, counter, Lat. tessera, such as were given to the dicasts, on presenting which they received their fee, 5. a permit or licence to reside, given to aliens; a ticket given by each person who joined in a picnic, to be presented for payment at the end (compare συμβολή IV), 6. in Eccl. the distinctive mark of Christians, a confession of faith, a creed, Lat. symbolum. 7. in legal phrase, σύμβολα were covenants between two states for protection of commerce, etc; σύμβολα ποιεῖσθαι πρὸς πόλιν to make a commercial treaty with a state, τὰ ς. συγχέειν to violate such treaty, (ML)

Poets Titan is the Sun-god. The oldest derivation of the name is given in, the stretchers, strivers; others connect it with τίτας (from τίνω); avengers. (ML)

G9519	τύχη	tuchē	good luck		1. the good which man obtains τυγχάνει); by the favour of the gods, good fortune, luck, success, etc; σὺν τύχῃ; θείᾳ τύχῃ, Lat. divinitus, etc; hence Τύχη was deified, like Lat. Fortuna, Τύχη Σώτειρα; T. Σωτήρ 2. generally, fortune, chance, good or bad, in singular and plural, attic 3. rarely of positive ill fortune, ἢν χρήσωνται τύχῃ, i. e. if they are killed; τύχῃ by ill-luck, 4. especially, ἀγαθὴ τ, etc; in dative ἀγαθῇ τύχῃ "in God's name, ", etc; by crasis, τύχἀγαθῇ;this formula was also introduced into treaties, like Lat. quod felix faustumque sit, Λάχης εἶπε, τύχῃ ἀγαθῇ τῶν Ἀθηναίων ποιεῖσθαι τὴν ἐκεχειρίαν Decret. in;so ἐπ᾽ ἀγαθῇ τύχῃ, etc. 5. Adverbial usages, τύχῃ by chance, Lat. forte, forte fortuna, etc; ἀπὸ τύχης; ἐκ τύχης; διὰ τύχην, etc; κατὰ τύχην, etc. 6. a chance, hap, accident, etc; τῆς τύχης, τὸ ἐμὲ τυχεῖν! what a piece of ill-luck, that; mostly of mishaps, misfortunes, etc. (ML)

Radic. sense, to pour: 2. properly of liquids, to pour out, pour, etc; Zeus χέει ὕδωρ, i. e. he makes it rain; χέει χιόνα βορέας; absolute, χέει it snows;Mid. to pour for oneself, especially of drink-offerings, χοὰς χεόμην νεκύεσσι, etc;Pass, χέονται κρῆναι they gush forth; χυθέντος ποτοῦ ἐς γῆν 3. χ. δάκρυα to shed tears;Pass, of tears, to pour or gush forth; so of blood, to be shed, 4. in Pass. to become liquid, melt, thaw, 5. of solids, to shed, scatter, φύλλα; πτερά; χ. κόνιν κὰκ κεφαλῆς; χ. καλάμην χθονί, of a mower or reaper (see. καλάμη), 6. like χώννυμι, to throw out earth, so as to form a mound, σῆμα, τύμβον χ. 7. χ. δοῦρα to pour or shower spears; Mid, βέλεα χέοντο they showered their arrows, 8. to let fall or drop, ἡνία; so, χέειν κρόκου βαφὰς (see. βαφή II); but, καρπὸν χ, of trees, to produce fruit abundantly, 9. in Pass. to be thrown or heaped up together, 10. in Pass. also of living beings, to pour or stream in a dense mass or throng, 11. metaphorically of sounds, to pour forth, φωνήν, αὐδήν; φθόγγον 12. of things that obscure the sight, κατ᾽ ὀφθαλμῶν χέεν ἀχλύν shed a dark cloud over the eyes; πολλὴν ἠέρα χεῦε shed a mist abroad;Pass, ἀμφὶ δέ οἱ θάνατος χύτο was shed around him; νόσος κέχυται; φρὶξ ἐπὶ πόντον ἐχεύατο (Mid. in passive sense), 13. of persons, ἀμφ᾽ αὐτῶι χυμένη throwing herself around him: so in Mid, ἀμφὶ υἱὸν ἐχεύατο πήχεε 14. perfect passive κέχυμαι, to be wholly engaged in, Δᾶλος, ἐν ἇι κέχυμαι (ML)

G9795	ψιλός	psilos	bare		1. bare, 2. of land, ψιλὴ ἄροσις a bare corn-field; πεδίον μέγα τε καὶ ψιλόν: with genitive, γῆ ψιλὴ δενδρέων land bare of trees; ψιλὴ γεωργία the tillage of land for corn, opp. to γ. πεφυτευμένη (for vines and olives), 3. of animals, stript of hair or feathers, bare, smooth, δέρμα; ἶβις ψιλὴ κεφαλήν bald on the head, 4. generally, bare, uncovered, ψιλὸν ὡς ὁρᾷ νέκυν;with genitive bare of, separated from, ψιλὴ σώματος οὖσα [ἡ ψυχή] b. bare, stript of appendages, ψιλὴ τρόπις the bare keel with the planks torn from it; ψ. θρίδαξ a lettuce with the side-leaves pulled off; ψ. μάχαιραι swords without other arms, 5. οἱ ψιλοί (i.e. τῶν ὅπλων); soldiers without heavy armour, light troops, such as archers and slingers, opp. to ὁπλῖται, etc; τὸ ψιλόν, opp. to τὸ ὁπλιτικόν; ψ. ἔχων τὴν κεφαλήν bare-headed, without helmet, 6. ψιλὸς λόγος bare language, i. e. prose, as opp. to poetry which is clothed in metre; also, ψ. λόγος is a mere speech, a speech unsupported by evidence, 7. ψιλὴ ποίησις mere poetry, without music, i. e. epic poetry, as opp. to lyric;but, ψιλὴ μουσική instrumental music unaccompanied by the voice, 8. Oedipus seems to call Antigone his ψιλὸν ὄμμα, as being the one poor eye left him, 9. adverb ψιλῶς, merely, only, (ML)
G9796	ψιλόω	psiloō	to make bear		1. to strip bare of hair; Pass. to become bald: generally, to be laid bare, 2. with genitive to strip bare of, to strip of a thing, 3. generally, to leave naked, unarmed or defenceless, 4. Pr, 47; Bl, §6, 8 Mayser, 166 f.), [in LXX chiefly for היה;] 1) of persons, things occurrences, to come into being, be born, arise, come on: Jhn.1:15 8:58, 1Co.15:37; a first appearance in public, Mrk.1:4, Jhn.1:6, al; before ἐκ (of birth), Rom.1:3, Gal.4:4; διά, Jhn.1:3; βροντή, Jhn.12:29; σεισμός, Rev.6:12; γογγυσμός, Act.6:1; χαρά, Act.8:8, many other similar exx; ἡμέρα, Luk.22:66, al; ὀψέ, Mrk.11:19; πρωΐα, Mat.27:1; νύξ, Act.27:27. 2) Of events, to come to pass, take place, happen: Mat.5:18, Mrk.5:14, Luk.1:20 2:15, Act.4:21, 2Ti.2:18, al; μὴ γένοιτο [LXX for חָלִילָה, Jhn.22:29, al.], far be it, God forbid: Rom.3:4 (ICC, in l.), 1Co.6:15 and freq. in Pl; καὶ ἐγένετο, ἐγένετο δέ ([in LXX for וַיְהִי;] see Burton, 142 f; M, Pr, 16f; Dalman, Words, 32 f; Robertson, Gr, 1042 f.), with indic, Mat.7:28, Luk.1:8, al; before καί and indic, Luk.8:1, Act.5:7, al; with accusative and inf, Mrk.2:23, Luk.3:21, al; ὡς δὲ ἐγένετο, before τοῦ with inf, Act.10:25; with dative of person(s), to befall one: with inf, Act.20:16; with accusative and inf, Act.22:6; with adv, εὖ, Eph.6:3; τ́ ἐγένετο αὐτῷ (Field, Notes, 115), Act.7:40 (LXX); before εἰς, Act.28:6. 3) to be made, done, performed, observed, enacted, ordained, etc: Mat.6:10 19:8, Mrk.2:27 11:23, Act.19:26, al; before διά with genitive, Mrk.6:2, Act.2:43; ὑπό, Luk.13:17; ἐκ, Luk.4:23; ἐν, 1Co.9:15; ἀπογραφή, Luk.2:2; ἀνάκρισις Act.25:26; ἄφεσις, Heb.9:22; ὁ νόμος, Gal.3:17; τὸ πάσχα, Mat.26:2. 4) to become, be made, come to be: with pred, Mat.4:3, Luk.4:3, Jhn.2:9, 1Co.13:11, al; before ὡς, ὡσεί, Mat.10:25, Mrk.9:26; εἰς (M, Pr, 71f.), Mrk.12:1 o, al; with genitive Rev.11:15; id, of age, Luk.2:42; with dative, γ. ἀνδρί ([LXX for הָיָה לְאִישׁ, Rut.1:12, al;] see Field, Notes, 156), Rom.7:3, 4; Adverbial usages, κύκλῳ in a circle or ring, round about, (Odyssey by Homer), attic; with genitive, κ. τοῦ στρατοπέδου (Xenophon Historicus), etc. 3. any circular body: 4. a wheel, (Iliad by Homer) 5. a place of assembly, the ἀγορά, (Iliad by Homer), attic;then, like Lat. corona, a ring or circle of people, (Sophocles Tragicus) 6. the vault of the sky, (Herdotus Historicus), etc. 7. the orb or disk of the sun and moon, (Herdotus Historicus), etc. 9. a round shield, see. above 1. 10. in plural the eye-balls, eyes, (Sophocles Tragicus);rarely in singular, the eye, (Sophocles Tragicus) 11. any circular motion, an orbit of the heavenly bodies, revolution of the seasons, cycle of events, (Herdotus Historicus) 12. a circular dance, (Aristophanes Comicus) (ML)

G20727	μὴ οὐ	mē ou	isn't it?		1. after Verbs expressing fear or apprehension, = Lat. vereor ut, δέδοικα μὴ οὐ γένηταί τι I fear it will not be; whereas δέδοικα μὴ γένηται mean, I fear it will be. Here, μή and οὐ each retain their proper force. 2. with Inf, 3. after Verbs of hindering, denying, avoiding, needing, when μὴ οὐ resembles Lat. quin or quominus, οὐδὲν κωλύει μὴ οὐκ ἀληθὲς εἶναι τοῦτο nihil impedit quin hoc verum sit; or with the Art, οὐδὲν ἐλλείψω τὸ μὴ οὐ πυθέσθαι nihil praetermittam quominus reperiam, (Sophocles Tragicus) 4. after Verbs signifying impossibility, impropriety, reluctance, μὴ οὐ has a negative translation, δεινὸν ἐδόκεε εἶναι μὴ οὐ λαβεῖν (Herdotus Historicus); αἰσχύνη ἦν μὴ οὐ δυσπουδάζειν (Xenophon Historicus) 5. μὴ οὐ with the Partic, only after a negative, expressed or implied, δυσάλγητος γὰρ ἂν εἤν μὴ οὐ κατοικτείρων I should be hard-hearted if I did not pity, (Sophocles Tragicus) 6. = εἰ μή, except πόλεις χαλεπαὶ λαβεῖν, μὴ οὐ πολιορκία (Demosthenes Orator) (ML)

G20810	νόος	noos	point		1. mind, perception, (Homer), etc; νόῳ heedfully, (Odyssey by Homer); παρὲκ νόον senselessly, (Iliad by Homer); σὺν νόῳ wisely, (Herdotus Historicus); νόῳ λαβεῖν τι to apprehend it, (Herdotus Historicus); νόῳ ἔχειν to keep in mind, (Herdotus Historicus) 2. νοῦν ἔχειν means 3. to have sense, be sensible, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc; περισσὰ πράσσειν οὐκ ἔχει νοῦν οὐδένα to aim too high has no sense, (Sophocles Tragicus) 4. to have one's mind directed to something, ἄλλος᾽ ὄμμα, θἀτέρᾳ δὲ νοῦν ἔχειν (Sophocles Tragicus); δεῦρο νοῦν ἔχε (Euripides) 5. the mind, heart, χαῖρε νόῳ (Odyssey by Homer); so, νόος ἔμπεδος, ἀπηνής (Homer); ἐκ παντὸς νόου with all his heart and soul, (Herdotus Historicus), etc. 6. one's mind, purpose, τί σοι ἐν νόῳ ἐστὶ ποιεῖ; what do you intend to do? (Herdotus Historicus); ἐν νόῳ ἔχειν, with infinitive, to intend, (Herdotus Historicus); νόον τελεῖν (Iliad by Homer) 7. the sense or meaning of a word or speech, (Herdotus Historicus) (ML)

G21066	πρύτανις	prutanis	president		1. a prince, ruler, lord, chief, of Hiero; of Zeus, 2. at Athens, a Prytanis or President: the πρυτάνεις were a committee of 50, chosen by lot from each of the 10 φυλαί, so that each set formed 1/10 part of the βουλή or Council of 500; out of these 50 πρυτάνεις one was chosen by lot as chief-president ἐπιστάτης); he chose 9 πρόεδρο; and the real business was in the hands of this smaller body, with a secretary γραμματεύς); added;The φυλή which first entered office every year was determined by lot; and their term of office πρυτανεία); was about five weeks. During this time all treaties and public acts ran in their name, in this form: Ἀκαμαντὶς φυλὴ, ἐπρυτάνευε, Φαίνιππος ἐγραμμάτευε, Νικιάδης ἐπεστάτει the Tribe Acamantis were the Presidency, Phaenippus the Secretary, Niciades the Chief-president, (ML)

G21365	ὠδίς	ōdis	[hudot]èbel		1. the pangs or throes of labour, travail-pains; ἐν μόναις ὠδῖσιν at a single birth; ἐν ὠδίνων ἀνάγκαις; in singular travail-pain, anguish, 2. in singular, also, the fruit of travail or labour, a birth, child; ἄπτερον ὠδῖνα τέκνων, of young birds, 3. metaphorically any travail, anguish; also in plural, of love, pangs, (ML)
G21366	ὤμιον	ōmion	small shoulder		small shoulder
G21367	ὠμότης	ōmotēs	savagery, fierceness, cruelty		rawness: metaphorically savageness, fierceness, cruelty, etc. (ML)
G21368	ὠμόφρων	ōmophrōn	savage-minded		savage-minded, savage, [variant dates Tragica Adespota adverb ὠμοφρόνως, (ML)
G21369	ὡραΐζω	hōraizō	to make display	G:V	make display (MT)
